abstract.p: Henry T Blanke letter on Sylvia Nasar's May 21 review of Francis Wheen's book Karl Marx: A Life holds Marx's book Das Kapital is critique of capitalism as socioeconomic system

block.p: In her review of Francis Wheen's ''Karl Marx: A Life'' (May 21), Sylvia Nasar writes that the author ''improbably'' asserts that ''all Marx's critics have either not read 'Das Kapital' or else misread it.'' She then proceeds to prove his point. Nasar rejects Wheen's defense of Marx by asking rhetorically if ''socialist societies that have dispensed with markets and democracy have succeeded.'' The implied idea that Marx created a blueprint for a socialist society that was actualized in the Soviet Union with disastrous results is common but mistaken. ''Das Kapital'' (and the great portion of Marx's vast oeuvre) is a critical analysis of capitalism as a socioeconomic system. It deals with the nature of commodities, the labor theory of value, financial crises and much else, but hardly at all with the shape of any future socialist society.
